sections.title: From Idea to Viable Business
sections.subtitle: Testing your business concept before investing time and money

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Techniques to validate business ideas quickly and cheaply
Market research methods for new ventures
Minimum viable product (MVP) development and testing

sections.title: The Importance of Idea Validation
sections.content: Most business ideas fail not because they're bad, but because they don't solve a real problem for enough people willing to pay. Validation helps you discover whether your idea has market potential before making significant investments of time and money.

points.title: Problem Validation
points.description: Confirm that your target customers actually experience the problem you want to solve.

points.title: Solution Validation
points.description: Test whether your proposed solution appeals to potential customers and meets their needs.

points.title: Market Validation
points.description: Assess market size, competition, and your ability to reach and convert customers profitably.

sections.title: Talk to Real Customers
sections.content: The best validation comes from direct customer conversations. Surveys and online research are helpful, but nothing replaces talking to 10-20 potential customers about their problems and your solution.

sections.title: Building a Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
sections.content: An MVP is the simplest version of your product that allows you to test your core assumptions. It could be a landing page, prototype, or even a manual process. The goal is learning, not perfection. Use tools like no-code platforms to build MVPs quickly and inexpensively.

sections.title: Validate Your Business Idea
steps: Identify 10-20 potential customers in your target market
Conduct problem interviews to understand their pain points
Create a simple landing page or prototype to test interest
Gather feedback and iterate based on what you learn

sections.title: Be Prepared to Pivot
sections.content: Your initial idea might not work, but the validation process often reveals better opportunities. Stay open to changing your approach based on customer feedback.
